canonical_explanation.text: The cell is the fundamental structural and functional unit of all living organisms. Robert Hooke first discovered cells in 1665 by observing cork under a microscope. The cell theory states that all living organisms are composed of cells, the cell is the basic unit of life, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells. Cells have a plasma membrane that is selectively permeable, controlling what enters and leaves the cell through osmosis and diffusion. Plant cells additionally have a rigid cell wall made of cellulose. The nucleus contains genetic material (DNA) organized as chromosomes. Important cell organelles include the endoplasmic reticulum (protein and lipid synthesis), Golgi apparatus (packaging and secretion), mitochondria (energy production via ATP), lysosomes (digestion of waste), and plastids (found only in plant cells). Cells are broadly classified as prokaryotic (lacking a membrane-bound nucleus, e.g., bacteria) and eukaryotic (having a membrane-bound nucleus, e.g., plant and animal cells). Cells reproduce through cell division — mitosis for growth and repair, and meiosis for producing gametes.
rules: The cell is the basic structural and functional unit of life.
Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 using a microscope.
Cell theory: all living things are made of cells; cell is the basic unit of life; new cells arise from pre-existing cells.
Plasma membrane is selectively permeable — allows certain substances in and out.
Osmosis is the movement of water from high to low concentration through a semipermeable membrane.
Diffusion is the movement of substances from high to low concentration.
Plant cells have a cell wall (cellulose) outside the plasma membrane; animal cells do not.
Nucleus contains DNA organized into chromosomes and controls cell activities.
Mitochondria are the powerhouse of the cell — produce ATP through cellular respiration.
Lysosomes are called suicide bags — contain digestive enzymes that break down waste.
Plastids (chloroplasts, chromoplasts, leucoplasts) are found only in plant cells.
Prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus; eukaryotic cells have one.
Plant cells have large central vacuoles; animal cells have small or no vacuoles.

questions.question_text: Who discovered cells for the first time?
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 when he observed thin slices of cork under a simple magnifying device. He saw small compartments which he named 'cells' because they resembled the small rooms (cellula) in a monastery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Anton van Leeuwenhoek observed living cells and microorganisms but did not discover cells first. Robert Brown discovered the nucleus, not the cell itself. Matthias Schleiden contributed to cell theory but was not the first to discover cells.

questions.question_text: The cell is called the structural and functional unit of life because:

options.text: All living organisms are made up of cells
Cells are very small in size
Cells can only be seen under a microscope
Cells are present only in animals

questions.explanation_correct: The cell is called the structural and functional unit of life because all living organisms are composed of one or more cells. Every living function — from nutrition and respiration to reproduction — is carried out at the cellular level.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While cells are small and often need a microscope to be seen, that is not the reason they are called the basic unit of life. Cells are present in all living organisms, not only animals.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a part of the cell theory?

options.text: All living organisms are composed of cells
Cells are the basic unit of life
All cells arise from pre-existing cells

questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'all cells contain a nucleus' is NOT part of the cell theory. Prokaryotic cells like bacteria do not have a membrane-bound nucleus. The three postulates of cell theory are: all living organisms are composed of cells, the cell is the basic unit of life, and all cells arise from pre-existing cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct postulates of cell theory as proposed by Schleiden, Schwann, and Virchow. The cell theory does not state that all cells must have a nucleus.

questions.question_text: Which organism is an example of a unicellular organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba is a unicellular organism, meaning it is made up of a single cell that performs all life functions such as nutrition, respiration, and reproduction. Rose plant, human being, and mango tree are all multicellular organisms composed of millions of cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rose plant, human being, and mango tree are multicellular organisms composed of many different types of cells organized into tissues and organs. Only Amoeba among the options is unicellular.

questions.question_text: The plasma membrane is called selectively permeable because:

options.text: It allows all substances to pass through
It does not allow any substance to pass through
It allows only certain substances to pass through

questions.explanation_correct: The plasma membrane is called selectively permeable because it allows only certain specific substances to pass through while preventing others. This selective permeability helps the cell maintain its internal environment and control the entry and exit of materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the membrane allowed all substances through, it would be freely permeable, not selectively permeable. If it blocked everything, it would be impermeable. The plasma membrane is made of a lipid bilayer with proteins, not cellulose (cellulose forms the cell wall).

questions.question_text: The movement of water molecules through a selectively permeable membrane from a region of high water concentration to a region of low water concentration is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Osmosis is the movement of water molecules from a region of higher water concentration (dilute solution) to a region of lower water concentration (concentrated solution) through a selectively permeable membrane. It is a special type of diffusion specific to water.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diffusion is the general movement of any substance from high to low concentration without requiring a membrane. Active transport moves substances against the concentration gradient using energy. Endocytosis is the ingestion of material by the cell membrane.

questions.question_text: When a dried raisin is placed in water, it swells up because of:
questions.explanation_correct: When a dried raisin is placed in water, water moves into the raisin cells by osmosis because the concentration of water outside the raisin is higher than inside. This causes the raisin to swell up as water enters its cells through the selectively permeable membrane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While osmosis is a type of diffusion, the specific process here is osmosis because it involves water movement through a selectively permeable membrane (cell membrane). Plasmolysis is the shrinking of cell contents, which is the opposite effect. Exosmosis means water moving out of the cell.

questions.question_text: If a plant cell is placed in a hypertonic solution, what will happen?

options.text: Nothing will happen to the cell

questions.explanation_correct: In a hypertonic solution (higher solute concentration outside), water moves out of the plant cell by exosmosis. The cell membrane shrinks away from the cell wall, a process called plasmolysis. The plant cell does not burst because the rigid cell wall holds its shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell will not swell up — that happens in a hypotonic solution. The cell will not burst because the rigid cell wall prevents it (unlike animal cells which can burst). The cell is affected because osmosis occurs due to the concentration difference.

questions.question_text: Which cell organelle is known as the 'powerhouse of the cell'?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are called the powerhouse of the cell because they produce energy in the form of ATP (adenosine triphosphate) through the process of cellular respiration. ATP is the energy currency used by cells for all their activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nucleus is the control centre of the cell, not the powerhouse. The Golgi apparatus is involved in packaging and secretion. The endoplasmic reticulum is involved in protein and lipid synthesis.

questions.question_text: Lysosomes are called 'suicide bags' because:

options.text: They produce energy for the cell
They contain digestive enzymes that can destroy the cell itself

questions.explanation_correct: Lysosomes are called suicide bags because they contain powerful digestive (hydrolytic) enzymes. If the cell is damaged or old, the lysosome membrane ruptures and the enzymes digest the cell's own contents, leading to cell death. This process is called autolysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy production is the function of mitochondria, not lysosomes. Cell division is controlled by the nucleus and centrioles. Storage of water and nutrients is the function of vacuoles.

questions.question_text: Which organelle is responsible for packaging and dispatching materials from the cell?
questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi apparatus (also called Golgi body or Golgi complex) is responsible for packaging materials synthesized in the cell and dispatching them to their destinations inside or outside the cell. It also forms lysosomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The endoplasmic reticulum synthesizes proteins and lipids but does not package them for dispatch. Ribosomes are the sites of protein synthesis. Lysosomes are involved in digestion of waste materials, not packaging.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organelles would be most abundant in cells that are very active and require a lot of energy, such as muscle cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria would be most abundant in very active cells like muscle cells because mitochondria produce ATP (energy) through cellular respiration. Cells that require more energy need more mitochondria to meet their energy demands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vacuoles are mainly for storage and are more prominent in plant cells. Lysosomes are for digestion of waste. Golgi apparatus is for packaging. None of these directly produce the energy that highly active cells need.

questions.question_text: A cell organelle has its own DNA and ribosomes, and can make some of its own proteins. Which organelle is this?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria have their own DNA and ribosomes, which makes them semi-autonomous organelles. They can synthesize some of their own proteins. Similarly, plastids (chloroplasts) in plant cells also have their own DNA and ribosomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Golgi apparatus, lysosomes, and endoplasmic reticulum do not have their own DNA or ribosomes. These organelles depend entirely on the nuclear DNA for their protein requirements.

questions.question_text: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) is primarily involved in:
questions.explanation_correct: The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) is primarily involved in the synthesis of lipids and steroids. It also plays a role in detoxification of drugs and poisons. It is called 'smooth' because it lacks ribosomes on its surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Protein synthesis occurs on the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), which has ribosomes attached to its surface. Photosynthesis occurs in chloroplasts. Cell division involves the nucleus and centrioles.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a prokaryotic organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Bacteria are prokaryotic organisms because they lack a membrane-bound nucleus. Their genetic material is found in the cytoplasm in a region called the nucleoid. They also lack other membrane-bound organelles like mitochondria and ER.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Amoeba, mushroom, and onion are all eukaryotic organisms. They have a well-defined membrane-bound nucleus and other membrane-bound organelles. Amoeba is a protist, mushroom is a fungus, and onion is a plant — all eukaryotes.

questions.question_text: The key difference between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells is:

options.text: Prokaryotic cells are larger than eukaryotic cells
Eukaryotic cells have a membrane-bound nucleus while prokaryotic cells do not
Prokaryotic cells have mitochondria while eukaryotic cells do not
Eukaryotic cells do not have a cell membrane

questions.explanation_correct: The fundamental difference between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells is that eukaryotic cells have a well-defined, membrane-bound nucleus containing their genetic material, while prokaryotic cells lack a membrane-bound nucleus and their DNA lies free in the cytoplasm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Prokaryotic cells are actually smaller than eukaryotic cells, not larger. Prokaryotic cells lack mitochondria; it is eukaryotic cells that have them. All cells, both prokaryotic and eukaryotic, have a cell membrane.

questions.question_text: Which of the following features is found in plant cells but NOT in animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells have a rigid cell wall made of cellulose and plastids (chloroplasts, chromoplasts, leucoplasts) that are absent in animal cells. The cell wall provides rigidity and shape, while plastids are involved in photosynthesis and storage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cell membrane, mitochondria, and nucleus are present in both plant and animal cells. Only cell wall and plastids are exclusive to plant cells among the options given.

questions.question_text: Which type of plastid is responsible for photosynthesis in plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Chloroplasts are the plastids responsible for photosynthesis in plants. They contain the green pigment chlorophyll, which captures sunlight energy and converts carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chromoplasts contain coloured pigments (other than green) that give flowers and fruits their colours. Leucoplasts are colourless plastids that store starch, oils, and proteins. Amyloplast is a type of leucoplast that stores starch.

questions.question_text: Which type of cell division results in two identical daughter cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Mitosis is the type of cell division that produces two identical daughter cells, each with the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell. Mitosis is important for growth, repair, and replacement of damaged cells in the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Meiosis produces four daughter cells with half the number of chromosomes and is used for gamete formation. Binary fission and budding are methods of asexual reproduction in organisms, not types of cell division in multicellular organisms.

questions.question_text: Meiosis is important because it:

options.text: Helps in growth of the organism
Produces gametes with half the chromosome number

questions.explanation_correct: Meiosis is important because it produces gametes (sex cells) with half the number of chromosomes (haploid). When two gametes fuse during fertilization, the normal (diploid) chromosome number is restored in the offspring.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growth and repair of damaged tissues are functions of mitosis, not meiosis. Identical daughter cells are produced by mitosis. Meiosis produces four genetically different daughter cells with half the chromosome number.

questions.question_text: Robert Brown discovered which part of the cell in 1831?
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Brown discovered the nucleus in 1831 while studying orchid cells under a microscope. The nucleus was later recognized as the control centre of the cell, containing the genetic material (DNA) that directs all cellular activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Robert Hooke described the cell wall when he observed cork cells. The cell membrane was described later by other scientists. Mitochondria were discovered by Richard Altmann in 1890. Robert Brown specifically discovered the nucleus.

questions.question_text: When a red blood cell is placed in distilled water, it will:
questions.explanation_correct: Distilled water is a hypotonic solution relative to the red blood cell. Water will enter the cell by osmosis (endosmosis), causing it to swell. Since animal cells lack a cell wall, the red blood cell will continue to swell and may eventually burst (haemolysis).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cell will not shrink — shrinking (crenation) occurs in a hypertonic solution. The cell will not remain the same because there is a concentration difference that drives osmosis. The cell swells due to water entry, it does not flatten.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about the endoplasmic reticulum is correct?

options.text: Rough ER synthesizes lipids and smooth ER synthesizes proteins
Rough ER has ribosomes on its surface and helps in protein synthesis
Both types of ER are involved in photosynthesis
ER is found only in prokaryotic cells

questions.explanation_correct: Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) has ribosomes attached to its surface, giving it a rough appearance. These ribosomes are the sites of protein synthesis. The RER helps in the synthesis and transport of proteins within the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the functions — rough ER synthesizes proteins (not lipids) and smooth ER synthesizes lipids (not proteins). ER is not involved in photosynthesis; that is the function of chloroplasts. ER is found in eukaryotic cells, not prokaryotic cells.

questions.question_text: A student observes a cell under a microscope and notes: it has a cell wall, a large central vacuole, chloroplasts, and a membrane-bound nucleus. This cell is most likely from a:
questions.explanation_correct: The combination of a cell wall, large central vacuole, chloroplasts, and a membrane-bound nucleus is characteristic of a plant cell from a green leaf. Chloroplasts indicate it is a photosynthetic part of the plant. The membrane-bound nucleus confirms it is eukaryotic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A bacterium is prokaryotic and lacks a membrane-bound nucleus, chloroplasts, and large vacuoles. Animal muscle tissue and human cheek lining cells lack cell walls, chloroplasts, and large central vacuoles.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Mitochondria are called semi-autonomous organelles.
Reason: Mitochondria have their own DNA and ribosomes.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are true, and reason is the correct explanation
Both assertion and reason are true, but reason is not the correct explanation
Assertion is true but reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.explanation_correct: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Mitochondria are called semi-autonomous because they possess their own DNA and ribosomes, enabling them to synthesize some of their own proteins independently of the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — mitochondria are indeed semi-autonomous. The reason is also true — they do have their own DNA and ribosomes. Furthermore, the reason correctly explains why they are semi-autonomous, making option A the correct choice.

questions.question_text: A human body cell has 46 chromosomes. After meiosis, each gamete will have:
questions.explanation_correct: Meiosis is a reduction division that produces gametes with half the number of chromosomes. Since human body cells have 46 chromosomes (diploid), each gamete produced after meiosis will have 23 chromosomes (haploid). This ensures that when two gametes fuse, the offspring has the correct 46 chromosomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 46 chromosomes would be the result of mitosis, not meiosis. 92 chromosomes would mean the chromosome number doubled, which does not happen in normal cell division. 12 chromosomes is not related to the human chromosome count.

questions.question_text: The process by which molecules of a substance move from a region of their higher concentration to a region of their lower concentration without the need for a membrane is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Diffusion is the spontaneous movement of molecules from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration. Unlike osmosis, diffusion does not require a semipermeable membrane and can occur in gases, liquids, and even solids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Osmosis specifically involves the movement of water through a semipermeable membrane. Active transport requires energy and moves substances against the concentration gradient. Plasmolysis is the shrinking of cell contents in a hypertonic solution.

questions.question_text: Which organelle would be affected first if a cell is unable to synthesize new proteins?
questions.explanation_correct: Ribosomes are the organelles directly responsible for protein synthesis. If a cell cannot synthesize new proteins, it indicates that the ribosomes are not functioning properly. Ribosomes read the mRNA instructions and assemble amino acids into proteins.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vacuoles are for storage, not protein synthesis. Chloroplasts are for photosynthesis. The cell wall is a non-living structure made of cellulose. None of these are directly responsible for protein synthesis like ribosomes are.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a difference between plant cells and animal cells?

options.text: Plant cells have small vacuoles while animal cells have large vacuoles
Animal cells have a cell wall while plant cells do not
Plant cells have a large central vacuole while animal cells have small or no vacuoles
Animal cells have chloroplasts while plant cells do not

questions.explanation_correct: Plant cells typically have a large central vacuole that can occupy up to 90% of the cell volume, maintaining turgor pressure and storing cell sap. Animal cells either have small, temporary vacuoles or none at all.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A reverses the facts — plant cells have large vacuoles. Option B is wrong — plant cells have cell walls, not animal cells. Option D is wrong — plant cells have chloroplasts, not animal cells.

questions.question_text: The cell theory was proposed by:
questions.explanation_correct: The cell theory was proposed by Matthias Schleiden (a botanist) and Theodor Schwann (a zoologist) in 1838-1839. They stated that all living organisms are made up of cells and the cell is the basic unit of life. Rudolf Virchow later added that all cells arise from pre-existing cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Robert Hooke discovered cells but did not propose cell theory. Robert Brown discovered the nucleus. Leeuwenhoek observed microorganisms. Virchow contributed to cell theory but was not its original proposer. Darwin worked on evolution and Mendel on genetics.

questions.question_text: A cell organelle that functions as a packaging and transport system and also forms lysosomes is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi apparatus functions as the packaging and transport system of the cell. It receives materials from the ER, modifies them, packages them into vesicles, and dispatches them. It also forms lysosomes by packaging hydrolytic enzymes into membrane-bound vesicles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The endoplasmic reticulum synthesizes proteins and lipids but does not form lysosomes. Mitochondria produce energy (ATP). The nucleus stores genetic material and controls cell activities. Only the Golgi apparatus performs both packaging and lysosome formation.

questions.question_text: Which type of cell division maintains the chromosome number constant across generations?
questions.explanation_correct: Meiosis reduces the chromosome number to half in gametes. When two gametes fuse during fertilization, the full chromosome number is restored. This combination of meiosis and fertilization maintains the chromosome number constant across generations in sexually reproducing organisms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitosis alone maintains chromosome number within an organism's body cells but does not involve gamete formation or fertilization. Meiosis alone only reduces the chromosome number. The combination of meiosis and fertilization is needed to maintain constancy across generations.

questions.question_text: Which component of the cell provides structural support and protection in plant cells but is absent in animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: The cell wall is a rigid layer made of cellulose that lies outside the plasma membrane in plant cells. It provides structural support, protection, and a fixed shape to the cell. Animal cells lack a cell wall, which is why they have irregular shapes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plasma membrane, cytoplasm, and nuclear membrane are all present in both plant and animal cells. Only the cell wall is exclusive to plant cells (among these options) and provides the rigid structural support.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organelles is NOT found in animal cells?
questions.explanation_correct: Chloroplasts are found only in plant cells (and some protists). They contain chlorophyll and are responsible for photosynthesis. Animal cells do not have chloroplasts because animals obtain their food by consuming other organisms rather than making it themselves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, and lysosomes are all found in animal cells. Mitochondria produce energy, Golgi apparatus packages materials, and lysosomes digest waste — all essential functions in animal cells.

questions.question_text: The organism in which cells were first observed by Robert Hooke was:
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke first observed cells in 1665 by examining thin slices of cork (oak bark) under a simple magnifying device. The dead cells of cork appeared as small box-like compartments, which he named 'cells'.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Onion peel is used in modern school experiments but was not what Hooke used. Human blood and pond water were studied by Leeuwenhoek, not Hooke. Hooke specifically used cork, which is the bark of the oak tree.

questions.question_text: All living organisms are made up of cells.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. According to cell theory, all living organisms are composed of one or more cells. Even the simplest organisms like bacteria are made of a single cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true, not false. Cell theory, proposed by Schleiden and Schwann, clearly states that all living organisms are made up of cells. There are no known living organisms that are not composed of cells.

questions.question_text: The cell wall is present in both plant cells and animal cells.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. The cell wall is present only in plant cells (made of cellulose), fungi (chitin), and bacteria (peptidoglycan). Animal cells do not have a cell wall; they only have a plasma membrane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Animal cells lack a cell wall. Only plant cells have a cell wall made of cellulose that provides rigidity and protection. Animal cells are bounded only by the flexible plasma membrane.

questions.question_text: Mitochondria are responsible for producing ATP, the energy currency of the cell.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Mitochondria carry out cellular respiration, breaking down glucose to produce ATP (adenosine triphosphate). ATP is used as the energy currency for all cellular activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Mitochondria are indeed the organelles that produce ATP through cellular respiration, which is why they are called the powerhouse of the cell.

questions.question_text: Prokaryotic cells contain membrane-bound organelles like mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Prokaryotic cells do not contain membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, or Golgi apparatus. These organelles are characteristic of eukaryotic cells only.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Prokaryotic cells are simpler in structure and lack all membrane-bound organelles including mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum. Only eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles.

questions.question_text: Mitosis produces four daughter cells with half the number of chromosomes.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Mitosis produces two (not four) daughter cells, each with the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell (not half). It is meiosis that produces four daughter cells with half the chromosome number.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Mitosis produces exactly two identical daughter cells with the same chromosome number as the parent. The description given matches meiosis, not mitosis.

questions.question_text: Lysosomes contain digestive enzymes and are formed by the Golgi apparatus.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Lysosomes are membrane-bound sacs filled with powerful digestive (hydrolytic) enzymes. They are formed by the Golgi apparatus, which packages these enzymes into vesicles that become lysosomes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Lysosomes do contain digestive enzymes and they are indeed formed by the Golgi apparatus. The Golgi apparatus packages hydrolytic enzymes into membrane-bound vesicles to create lysosomes.

questions.question_text: Osmosis can occur without a selectively permeable membrane.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Osmosis specifically requires a selectively permeable membrane. It is defined as the movement of water molecules from a region of higher water concentration to a region of lower water concentration through a selectively permeable membrane. Without the membrane, the process would simply be diffusion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. A selectively permeable membrane is an essential requirement for osmosis to occur. Without it, the movement of water would be classified as diffusion, not osmosis.

questions.question_text: The cell was first discovered by ___ in 1665.
questions.explanation_correct: Robert Hooke discovered cells in 1665 when he observed thin slices of cork under a primitive microscope. He named the small compartments he saw 'cells' because they resembled the cells (small rooms) of a monastery.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Robert Hooke'. He was the first person to observe and describe cells in 1665 using thin slices of cork. Other scientists like Leeuwenhoek, Brown, and Schleiden made important contributions later.

questions.question_text: The ___ is called the powerhouse of the cell because it produces ATP.
questions.explanation_correct: Mitochondria are called the powerhouse of the cell because they carry out cellular respiration and produce ATP (adenosine triphosphate), which is the energy currency used by cells for all their activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'mitochondria'. No other organelle is referred to as the powerhouse of the cell. Mitochondria specifically produce ATP through the process of cellular respiration.

questions.question_text: The movement of water through a selectively permeable membrane is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Osmosis is the process by which water molecules move from a region of higher water concentration to a region of lower water concentration through a selectively permeable membrane. It is a special type of diffusion.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'osmosis'. While diffusion is the general movement of molecules from high to low concentration, osmosis specifically refers to the movement of water through a selectively permeable membrane.

questions.question_text: Cells that lack a membrane-bound nucleus are called ___ cells.
questions.explanation_correct: Prokaryotic cells are cells that lack a membrane-bound nucleus. The term 'prokaryotic' literally means 'before nucleus'. In these cells, the genetic material (DNA) lies free in the cytoplasm in a region called the nucleoid. Examples include bacteria and cyanobacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'prokaryotic'. Cells with a membrane-bound nucleus are called eukaryotic cells. Prokaryotic cells are simpler, smaller, and lack all membrane-bound organelles.

questions.question_text: The ___ are called suicide bags of the cell because they can digest the cell itself when it is damaged.
questions.explanation_correct: Lysosomes are called the suicide bags of the cell because they contain powerful digestive (hydrolytic) enzymes. When a cell is damaged beyond repair, the lysosome membrane ruptures, releasing these enzymes which then digest the entire cell contents — a process called autolysis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'lysosomes'. No other organelle is called the suicide bag. Lysosomes specifically contain hydrolytic enzymes that can destroy the cell itself when needed.

questions.question_text: The type of cell division that produces gametes with half the chromosome number is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Meiosis is the reductive cell division that produces four daughter cells (gametes), each with half the number of chromosomes of the parent cell. This is essential for sexual reproduction to maintain a constant chromosome number across generations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'meiosis'. Mitosis produces two identical daughter cells with the same chromosome number. Meiosis is the specific type of division that halves the chromosome number to form gametes.

questions.question_text: The organelle that packages materials and dispatches them from the cell is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The Golgi apparatus (also called Golgi body or Golgi complex) is responsible for packaging materials synthesized within the cell into vesicles and dispatching them to their target locations, either within or outside the cell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Golgi apparatus'. While the endoplasmic reticulum synthesizes proteins and lipids, it is the Golgi apparatus that receives, modifies, packages, and dispatches these materials.

questions.question_text: The shrinking of cell contents in a plant cell placed in a hypertonic solution is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Plasmolysis is the process in which the cell membrane of a plant cell shrinks away from the cell wall when the cell is placed in a hypertonic solution. Water leaves the cell by exosmosis, causing the protoplasm to contract and pull away from the cell wall.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'plasmolysis'. This occurs specifically in plant cells placed in a hypertonic solution. The reverse process, where the cell regains water and the membrane returns to its normal position, is called deplasmolysis.
